name: DEPRECATED: EJB Entity access through their local Interface
description:
For application using EJB 2.0, EJB Entities should be accessed through their local Interface instead of their remote Interface
In EJB 2.0, a bean that is destined to be remote extends EJBObject in its remote interface and EJBHome in its home interface.

For application using EJB 2.0, EJB Entities should be accessed through their local Interface instead of their remote Interface", 

>> All application using EJB 2.0 should use local interface?? what if the client is not in the same JVM? In that case EJB has to use remote interface (if not using session facade pattern)
>> If we are to check this condition only when the session facade pattern is used then total needs to be changed.
output:
This report lists all the Methods using the EJB Entity remote Interfaces.
It provides the following information:
 - Method full name
 - Entity Java Bean Name
rationale:
Best practices recommend that Entity beans only use Local Interface methods to expose their functions. So since, EJB 2.0, remote interface should not be used. Instead, opt for local interface as part of session façade implementation. 
This avoids the need for the JNDI lookup, which improves the performance
reference: Enterprise Java Programming with IBM WebSphere - page 508
remediation: Review the source code and have the EJB Entities accessed through their local  Interface instead of their remote Interface.
total: Number of Methods accessing Java EJB Entity
alternativeName: Ensure that EJB Entities are accessed through their local  Interface instead of their remote interface.
